status.full_text: @benjamin @p_pugliese Yes: https://t.co/ZVP7PseZ5Y is a collection of his work by his students.
@benjamin @p_pugliese he died before he could write books leaving a body of 35 years of studies behind. You have to work with that...
@dc7590 The show is brilliant. Watch it!
An average Spanish supermarket ... https://t.co/2AI5UCFpSf
What is a good and short expression for writing software that supports business goals?
I'm struggling to find a good title for the @RH_Way tech blog. https://t.co/40EVUiEsIs
@w3ltraumpirat At @RH_Way everything we do must contribute towards creating customer value. You must answer this for your own work (which
@w3ltraumpirat you chose yourself). Therefore IT can't be a means to itself but must also provide customer value. I'd like to put an

@w3ltraumpirat emphasis on this in then tech blog. 
There are many topics around this, that fascinate me, e.g. feature agility, tech debt.
@w3ltraumpirat That title should reflect the strive to create IT systems that support this idea.
@RH_Way Who do we want to provoce?
@fdeberle You see me running ...
.@w3ltraumpirat "codifying customer value"
@RH_Way that is the "what", the blog will talk about the "how".
@w3ltraumpirat if it isn't, don't do it. I must be able to connect a line of code to a customer value. If not, who is paying for it?
@w3ltraumpirat which improves product quality, development speed. The customer benefits. It's an indirect connection, though. But important
@w3ltraumpirat to know WHY we are doing it and where the money comes from.
Actually that tech blog will be more like a wiki. Posts don't make sense when documenting concepts+implementations. https://t.co/JZEyqVDuJ8
Yes, that is a good inspiration: https://t.co/f42gjFLTEY https://t.co/fp54uou12j

Very true! When I moved from PHP to NodeJS I immediately looked for DI which I knew from @symfony, but it turns out: https://t.co/apP8w5D6vf
@coderbyheart if your code is S.O.L.I.D, the D makes sure you can test your modules without a DI container. I've made fairly complex apps
@coderbyheart since then with a lot of separate libraries but a DI container/framework is no longer on my wishlist. Defining your building
@coderbyheart blocks in one location is nice but you add new configuration semantics on top of your languages "module" loader, which adds
@coderbyheart complexity. And resolving the actual configuration in your IDE is also no longer trivial and highly framework specific.

Yes, IMO a real problem. Face to face meetings favor quick, reactive people (usually extroverts). Make time around https://t.co/F9YX3jFMqv
@coderbyheart meetings (prepare schedule, decision points) and don't force decisions during meetings. Postpone to give introverts time to
@coderbyheart find their opinion in a way that suits them best.

@benjamin I find the idea that titles serve a purpose rather funny. Nobody wants to work in a setting were you can pull rank, anymore.
@benjamin for what do you need to title your coworkers?
@benjamin on a side note: I've nearly finished "everyone culture", they also advocate that titles or seniority is actually not important.
@benjamin clinging on our striving for your next stripe on the shoulder cements the status quo and limits the ability to change of an org.
@calibanatspace der Prototyp funzt also, bis er auf die Realit√§t trifft ;:-)
@benjamin I'll post a review of the book soon. They are not gurus, they've studied the topic for many years and make some solid points.
@benjamin on externals: but they usually don't match because they are not asswarded based on the same principles.
@benjamin except: CEO, Gesch√§ftsf√ºhrer, because those are legally binding.

@benjamin it helps to have role or function of a person, but that's often too simplistic.
Adding seniority modifiers bears no real meaning.
@benjamin I think we should replace titles with sth better: a skill tree that encourages constant learning g and also reflects the orgs need
Blog post series coming up about this: https://t.co/st1AO6uQuO
